segment: Governor Kasich, Senator Cruz is so committed to stripping federal funds from Planned Parenthood that it could result in shutting down the federal government in just about two weeks. Do you agree with Senator Cruz's tactic?
speaker: bash

segment: Well, I agree that we should defund Planned Parenthood. I don't know many people in America who don't think that we should, and in my state, we're trying to figure out how to get it done, because we are threatened with the federal government taking all of our Medicaid money away.
speaker: kasich

segment: I think there is a way to get this done by giving governors the ability to be able to act to defund Planned Parenthood. But when (ph) it comes to closing down the federal government, you gotta be very careful about that.
speaker: kasich

segment: When we shut the government down — if we have a chance at success and it's a great principle, yes. The president of the United States is not going to sign this, and all we're gonna do is shut the government down, and then we're gonna open up — open it up, and the American people are gonna shake their heads and say, "what's the story with these Republicans?"
speaker: kasich

segment: So I think there is a way to get to cutting off the funding for Planned Parenthood. I was in the Congress for 18 years, balanced the budget, cut taxes, got it done. Changed welfare, went around the president to get welfare reform done.
speaker: kasich

segment: There are ways to do it without having to shut the government down, but I'm sympathetic to the fact that we don't want this organization to get funding, and the money ought to be reprogrammed for family planning in other organizations that don't support this tactic.
speaker: kasich

segment: But I would not be for shutting the government down...
speaker: kasich

segment: Thank you.
speaker: bash

segment: ...because I don't think it's going to work out.
speaker: kasich

segment: Thank you.
speaker: bash

segment: Senator Cruz, I would just add that, on this stage not that long ago, Senator Graham said that this tactic that you're pushing would tank the Republicans' ability to win in 2016.
speaker: bash

segment: Well, let me tell you, Dana, number one, I'm proud to stand for life. These Planned Parenthood videos are horrifying. I would encourage every American to watch the videos. See — seeing your Planned Parenthood officials callously, heartlessly bartering and selling the body parts of human beings, and then ask yourself, "are these my values?"
speaker: cruz

segment: These are horrifying. On these videos, Planned Parenthood also essentially confesses to multiple felonies. It is a felony with ten years' jail term to sell the body parts of unborn children for profit. That's what these videos show Planned Parenthood doing.
speaker: cruz

segment: Absolutely we shouldn't be sending $500 million of taxpayer money to funding an ongoing criminal enterprise, and I'll tell you, the fact that Republican leadership in both houses has begun this discussion by preemptively surrendering to Barack Obama and saying, "we'll give in because Obama threatens a veto."
speaker: cruz

segment: You know, Obama's committed to his principles. His liberal principles, he will fight for them. He says...
speaker: cruz

segment: Thank you, senator.
speaker: bash

segment: I will veto any budget that doesn't fund Planned Parenthood, and Republicans surrender. We need to stop surrendering and start standing...
speaker: cruz

segment: Thank you...
speaker: bash

segment: ...for our principles.
speaker: cruz

segment: Governor — governor, I want to go to you. Is it what Senator Cruz says, a surrender by Republicans?
speaker: bash

segment: We're not — what I can tell you is this. We didn't surrender in New Jersey, six years ago, as the brand new first ever pro-life governor of New Jersey since Roe versus Wade, I defended Planned Parenthood.
speaker: kasich

segment: And I've vetoed Planned Parenthood funding, now, eight times in New Jersey. Since the day I walked in as governor, Planned Parenthood has not been funded in New Jersey. We stood up and every one of those vetoes has been sustained.
speaker: kasich

segment: But here's the problem, we're — we're fighting with each other up here. We agree. Let's ask Hillary Clinton. She believes in the systematic murder of children in the womb to preserve their body parts...
speaker: kasich

segment: But...
speaker: bash

segment: ...Dana, in a way that maximizes their value for sale for profit. It is disgusting, and the American people need to hear it...
speaker: kasich

segment: But is it...
speaker: bash

segment: ...we shouldn't be fighting with each other. She's the real opponent, she's the real problem.
speaker: kasich

segment: But, governor, the — but, governor, the reality is, in just two weeks' time...  ...we are going to be facing a question about whether or not it's enough to shut down the government to make that statement, because there is still a Democrat in the White House. Do you oppose it or support it?
speaker: bash

segment: I'll tell you what — I'll tell you what I'd be willing to fight for. I'll tell you what I'd be willing to fight for. Why will (ph) we put tax reform on the president's desk, so we can simplify this tax system?
speaker: kasich

segment: Yes or no, do you support this shutdown?
speaker: bash

segment: No, no, it's really important, Dana. We got to talk about what we would be willing to shut down for. Why don't we put tax reform on this president's desk, and make him veto it if that's what he wants to do? Why haven't we repealed and replaced Obamacare?
speaker: kasich

segment: Make him veto if that's what he wants to do.
speaker: kasich

segment: We're talking about Planned Parenthood right now.
speaker: bash

segment: And why don't we do the same thing with Planned Parenthood?
speaker: christie

segment: Can you answer yes or no?
speaker: bash

segment: We elected a Republican Congress to do this. And they should be doing it, and they're not. And they're giving the president a pass.
speaker: christie

segment: Dana, I'd like to...
speaker: fiorina

segment: One more time. I'm sorry, I just want to get the answer.
speaker: bash

segment: I put it in the list, Dana. We should be doing these things and forcing the president to take action.
speaker: christie

segment: So you would support a shutdown.
speaker: bash

segment: Let's force him to do what he says he's going to do. Now I don't know whether he'll do it or not, but let's force him to do it.
speaker: christie

segment: Dana, I would like to link these two issues, both of which are incredibly important, Iran and Planned Parenthood.
speaker: fiorina

segment: One has something to do with the defense of the security of this nation. The other has something to do with the defense of the character of this nation. You have not heard a plan about Iran from any politician up here, here is my plan. On day one in the Oval Office, I will make two phone calls, the first to my good friend to Bibi Netanyahu to reassure him we will stand with the state of Israel.
speaker: fiorina

segment: The second, to the supreme leader, to tell him that unless and until he opens every military and every nuclear facility to real anytime, anywhere inspections by our people, not his, we, the United States of America, will make it as difficult as possible and move money around the global financial system.
speaker: fiorina

segment: We can do that, we don't need anyone's cooperation to do it. And every ally and every adversary we have in this world will know that the United States in America is back in the leadership business, which is how we must stand with our allies.
speaker: fiorina

segment: As regards Planned Parenthood, anyone who has watched this videotape, I dare Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama to watch these tapes. Watch a fully formed fetus on the table, it's heart beating, it's legs kicking while someone says we have to keep it alive to harvest its brain.
speaker: fiorina

segment: This is about the character of our nation, and if we will not stand up in and force President Obama to veto this bill, shame on us.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Dana, I want to continue on the subject.
speaker: tapper

segment: Governor Bush, you recently said while discussing Planned Parenthood, quote, you're "not sure we need a half billion for women's health issues." Now you've since said that you misspoke, you didn't mean to say "women's health issues."
speaker: tapper

segment: But Donald Trump said that quote, that comment, which Hillary Clinton did seize upon immediately, will haunt you the same way Mitt Romney's 47 percent video haunted him.
speaker: tapper

segment: Tell Donald Trump why he's wrong.
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, he's wrong on a lot of things, but on this he's wrong because I'm the most pro-life governor on this stage. I got to act on my core beliefs. It's part of who I am. Life is a gift from God. And from beginning end we need to respect it and err on the side of life.
speaker: bush

segment: And so I defunded Planned Parenthood. We created a climate where parental notification took place. We were the only state to fund crisis pregnancy centers with state moneys. We were totally focused on this. And I would bring that kind of philosophy to Washington, D.C.
speaker: bush

segment: So here is a solution to this. Title X of the HHS funding, there is something that was the "Reagan Rule." It was passed in 1988. And in that rule it was defined, and the courts approved this, that a Planned Parenthood, you couldn't separate the money between the actual abortion procedures, and there are 330,000 abortions that take place in this clinic, and their promotion of it.
speaker: bush

segment: He interpreted it the right way, the courts ruled in his favor, and Planned Parenthood did not get funding during that time until President Clinton came in.
speaker: bush

segment: When I'm elected president, we will restore that interpretation of Title X. And this deal will be finished.
speaker: bush

segment: Thank you, Governor Bush.
speaker: tapper

segment: Donald Trump, let me just...
speaker: tapper

segment: Jeb, just...
speaker: trump

segment: The quote was, "I'm not sure we need half a billion dollars for women's health issues." He said he misspoke. You said that that's going to haunt him. Why do you think that?
speaker: tapper

segment: I think it will haunt him. I think it's a terrible. I think it's going to haunt him absolutely. He came back later and he said he misspoke. There was no question because I heard when he said the statement. I was watching and he said the statement.
speaker: trump

segment: And I said, wow, I can't believe it. I will take care of women. I respect women. I will take care of women.
speaker: trump

segment: One thing we will say and I would like to get back to the Iran situation. We're talking about Iran. The agreement was terrible. It was incompetent. I've never seen anything like it. One of the worst contracts of any kind I've ever seen.
speaker: trump

segment: And nobody ever mentions North Korea where you have this maniac sitting there and he actually has nuclear weapons and somebody better start thinking about North Korea and perhaps a couple of other places. But certainly North Korea.
speaker: trump

segment: And Ted and I have spoken. We've — a lot of us have spoken. We're talking about Iran. They are bad actors, bad things are going to happen. But in the meantime, you have somebody right now in North Korea who has got nuclear weapons and who is saying almost every other week, I'm ready to use them. And we don't even mention it.
speaker: trump

segment: Governor Bush?
speaker: tapper

segment: There are 13,000 community-based organizations that provide health services to women, 13,000 in this country. I don't believe that Planned Parenthood should get a penny from the federal government. Those organizations should get funding, just as I increased funding when I was governor of the state.
speaker: bush

segment: That's the way you do this is you improve the condition for people. And, Donald, when I was governor, we also increased the opportunities for women.
speaker: bush

segment: Women's income grew three times faster than the national average when I was governor.
speaker: bush

segment: So why didn't you say it? Why didn't you say it?
speaker: trump

segment: We improved — we improved —
speaker: bush

segment: I know, but why did you say it? I heard it myself. Why did you say it?
speaker: trump

segment: — we increased child support — we increased child support with a broken system by 90 percent.
speaker: bush

segment: You said you're going to cut funding for women's health. You said it.
speaker: trump

segment: I have a proven record. I have a proven record.
speaker: bush

segment: You said it.
speaker: trump

segment: I want to — we're going to get to —
speaker: tapper

segment: Jake, just one more moment. This is — there's something bigger to this. Now, I — like so many other governors here, I defunded Planned Parenthood four-and-a-half years ago, in a Blue State. But it's bigger than that. We did that in a Blue State, we took the money and put it into women's health, so we did exactly what we're talking about here.
speaker: walker

segment: But I think the bigger issue here is we should be able to do this nationally, and this is precisely why so many Republicans are upset with Washington. They see the House and they see the Senate and they say why can't we pass this. Why can't we defund Planned — put it in a spending bill.
speaker: walker

segment: Forget about the 60-vote rule, there's no reason — and the Constitution doesn't call for 60 votes. Pass it with 51 votes, put it on the desk of the president —
speaker: walker

segment: Thank you, Governor.
speaker: tapper

segment: — and go forward and actually make a point. This is why —
speaker: walker

segment: Thank you, Governor.
speaker: tapper

segment: — people are upset with Washington.
speaker: walker

segment: We're going to — we're going to get to many of these issues. This — we're still in the first block, believe it or not. We're going to get to many of these issues, but before we end this block, Ms. Fiorina, I do want to ask you about this.
speaker: tapper

segment: In an interview last week in Rolling Stone magazine, Donald Trump said the following about you. Quote, "Look at that face. Would anyone vote for that? Can you imagine that, the face of our next president?" Mr. Trump later said he was talking about your persona, not your appearance. Please feel free to respond what you think about his persona. [laughter]
speaker: tapper

segment: You know, it's interesting to me, Mr. Trump said that he heard Mr. Bush very clearly and what Mr. Bush said. I think women all over this country heard very clearly what Mr. Trump said.
speaker: fiorina

segment: I think she's got a beautiful face, and I think she's a beautiful woman.

segment: All right. On that note, in less than two minutes — we're going to take a very quick break. In less than two minutes, the most contentious issue on the campaign trail. And the candidates on the stage are split over how to handle it. That's coming up next.

segment: Please give some applause to the candidates.

speaker: tapper

segment: Welcome to CNN's Republican Presidential Debate. No topic perhaps has been more combustible in this campaign than the issue of immigration.
speaker: tapper

segment: Mr. Trump, you have called for deporting every undocumented immigrant, Governor Christie has said, quote, "There are not enough law enforcement officers — local, county, state and federal combined — to forcibly deport 11 to 12 million people."
speaker: tapper

segment: Tell Governor Christie how much your plan will cost, and how you will get it done.
speaker: tapper

segment: Correct. First of all, I want to build a wall, a wall that works. So important, and it's a big part of it.
speaker: trump

segment: Second of all, we have a lot of really bad dudes in this country from outside, and I think Chris knows that, maybe as well as anybody.
speaker: trump

segment: They go, if I get elected, first day they're gone. Gangs all over the place. Chicago, Baltimore, no matter where you look.
speaker: trump

segment: We have a country based on laws. I will make sure that those laws are adhered to. These are illegal immigrants. I don't think you'd even be asking this question if I didn't run because when I ran, and I brought this up, my opening remarks at Trump Tower, I took heat like nobody has taken heat in a long time. And, then they found out with the killing of Katie, from San Francisco, and so many other crimes, they found out that I was right.
speaker: trump

segment: And, most people, many people, apologized to me. I don't think you'd even be talking about illegal immigration if it weren't for me. So, we have a country of laws, they're going to go out, and they'll come back if they deserve to come back. If they've had a bad record, if they've been arrested, if they've been in jail, they're never coming back. We're going to have a country again. Right now, we don't have a country, we don't have a border, and we're going to do something about it, and it can be done with proper management, and it can be done with heart.
speaker: trump

segment: Governor Christie, you and I have talked about this in an interview. You say that his big wall, his plan to deport 11 to 12 million undocumented immigrants, it sounds great, but it's never going to happen.
speaker: tapper

segment: Tell him why you're skeptical of his plans?
speaker: tapper

segment: First of, Jake, I don't yield to anybody on how to enforce the law. I'm the only person on this stage who spent seven years as a United States Attorney after September 11th, and I know how to do this.
speaker: christie

segment: The fact is though that for 15,000 people a day to be deported every day for two years is an undertaking that almost none of us could accomplish given the current levels of funding, and the current number of law enforcement officers. Here's what we need to do, and I think this is where Donald is absolutely right. What we need to do is to secure our border, and we need to do it with more than just a wall.
speaker: christie

segment: We need to use electronics, we need to use drones, we need to use FBI, DEA, and ATF, and yes, we need to take the fingerprint of every person who comes into this country on a visa, and when they overstay their visa, we need to tap them on the shoulder, and say, "You have overstayed your welcome, you're taking advantage of the American people. It's time for you to go."
speaker: christie

segment: If we had that kind of system in place, we wouldn't have the 11 million people we have now.
speaker: christie

segment: Thank you, Governor Christie...
speaker: tapper

segment: ...By the way, I agree with — with what Chris is saying, but, I will say this. Illegal immigration is costing us more than $200 billion dollars a year just to maintain what we have.
speaker: trump

segment: I want to bring in Dr. Carson because he too has been skeptical of your plan to immediately deport 11 to 12 million illegal immigrants. He said, quote, "People who say that have no idea what this entails."
speaker: tapper

segment: Why do you say that, Dr. Carson?
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, first of all, I recognize that we have an incredible illegal immigration problem. I was down in Arizona a few weeks ago at the border. I mean, the fences that were there were not manned, and those are the kind of fences when I was a kid that would barely slow us down. So, I don't see any purpose in having that.
speaker: carson

segment: Now, what we need to do is look at something that actually works. Yuma County, Arizona. They stop 97 percent of the illegal immigrants through there. They put in a double fence with a road so that there was quick access by the enforcement people.
speaker: carson

segment: If we don't seal the border, the rest of this stuff clearly doesn't matter. It's kind of ridiculous all the other things we talk about. We have the ability to do it, we don't have the will to do it.
speaker: carson

segment: There was one area where they had cut a hole in the fence, and to repair it, they put a few strands of barb wire across. Well, the photographers who were there with us, they wanted to photograph us from the side of the Mexicans, and they went through there, and they were not physically fit people, and they took their cameras and things with them, and shot us from the other side.
speaker: carson

segment: That's how easy it is to get across. And, the drugs, I mean, it goes on, and on, and on. ICE tells them to release these people, 67,000 criminals released...
speaker: carson

segment: ...Dr. Carson...
speaker: tapper

segment: ...on to our property, it's ridiculous.
speaker: carson

segment: With all due respect, you said about Donald Trump's plan to deport 11 to 12 million undocumented immigrants, "People who say that have no idea what this entails."
speaker: tapper

segment: Why not?
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, I have also said, if anybody knows how to do that, that I would be willing to listen. And, if they can, you know, specify exactly how that's going to be done, and what the cost, and it sounds reasonable, then I think it's worth discussing...
speaker: carson

segment: TRUMP(?): ...[inaudible]...
speaker: trump

segment: ...let's continue the conversation about illegal immigration with Dana Bash.
speaker: tapper

segment: He did, he did. You're proud of your family, just as I am.

segment: Correct.

segment: Good.

segment: Yeah.

segment: But I do hear she's a lovely woman.

segment: So, here's the deal. My wife is a Mexican-American. She's an American by choice.

segment: She loves this country as much as anybody in this room, and she wants a secure border. But she wants to embrace the traditional American values that make us special and make us unique.
speaker: bush

segment: We're at a crossroads right now. Are we going to take the Reagan approach, the hopeful optimistic approach, the approach that says that, you come to our country legally, you pursue your dreams with a vengeance, you create opportunities for all of us?
speaker: bush

segment: Or the Donald Trump approach? The approach that says that everything is bad, that everything is coming to an end. I...

segment: Mr. Trump?

segment: Jeb said...

segment: I'm on the Reagan side of this.
speaker: bush

segment: ... that they come into our country as an act of love.
speaker: trump

segment: With all of the problems we that we have, in so many instances — we have wonderful people coming in. But with all of the problems — this is not an act of love. He's weak on immigration — by the way, in favor of Common Core, which is also a disaster, but weak on immigration.
speaker: trump

segment: He doesn't get my vote.
speaker: trump

segment: Mr. Trump...
speaker: bash

segment: Dana, with all being said to Mr. Trump...
speaker: fiorina

segment: Go ahead.
speaker: bash

segment: Immigration did not come up in 2016 because Mr. Trump brought it up. We talked about it in 2012, we talked about it in 2008. We talked about it in 2004.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Not with this intensity.
speaker: trump

segment: We have been talking about it for 25 years. This is why people are tired of politicians.

segment: Ms. Fiorina — Ms. Fiorina, we're going to come to you, we're going to come to you.
speaker: bash

segment: I just want to give Governor Bush a chance to respond to what Mr. Trump said.
speaker: bash

segment: Look, first of all, I wrote a book about this, three — four years ago, now. And I laid out a comprehensive, conservative approach for immigration reform.
speaker: bush

segment: And it does require securing the border. No one disagrees with that. But to build a wall, and to deport people — half a million a month — would cost hundreds of billions of dollars, Donald. Hundreds of billions of dollars. It would destroy community life, it would tear families apart.
speaker: bush

segment: And it would send a signal to the rest of the world that the United States values that are so important for our long-term success no longer matter in this country.
speaker: bush

segment: As I said, we are spending $200 billion — we are spending $200 billion a year on maintaining what we have. We will move them out. The great ones will come back, the good ones will come back.
speaker: trump

segment: They'll be expedited, they'll be back, they'll come back legally. We'll have a country — they'll come back, legally.

segment: OK, on that note, you have criticized Governor Bush for speaking Spanish on the campaign trail. You said, quote, "He should really set an example by speaking English in the United States."
speaker: bash

segment: What's wrong with speaking Spanish?
speaker: bash

segment: Well, I think it's wonderful and all, but I did it a little bit half-heartedly, but I do mean it to a large extent.
speaker: trump

segment: We have a country, where, to assimilate, you have to speak English. And I think that where he was, and the way it came out didn't sound right to me. We have to have assimilation — to have a country, we have to have assimilation.
speaker: trump

segment: I'm not the first one to say this, Dana. We've had many people over the years, for many, many years, saying the same thing. This is a country where we speak English, not Spanish.
speaker: trump

segment: Well, I've been speaking English here tonight, and I'll keep speaking English.
speaker: bush

segment: But the simple fact is, if a high school kid asks me a question in Spanish, a school — by the way, a voucher program that was created under my watch, the largest voucher program in the country, where kids can go to a Christian school, and they ask me a question in Spanish, I'm going to show respect and answer that question in Spanish.
speaker: bush

segment: Even though they do speak English, and even though they embrace American values.
speaker: bush

segment: This is a reporter, not a high school kid.
speaker: trump

segment: Ms. Dana, I agree that English is the unifying language of our country, and everyone should learn to speak it. It's important.
speaker: rubio

segment: I want to tell you a story about someone that didn't speak English that well. It was my grandfather; he came to this country in the 1960s, as a — escaping Cuba. And he lived with us, growing up.
speaker: rubio

segment: And my grandfather loved America. He understood what was so special about this country. He loved Ronald Reagan; he would be very proud of the fact that we're here this evening.
speaker: rubio

segment: My grandfather instilled in me the belief that I was blessed to live in the one society in all of human history where even I, the son of a bartender and a maid, could aspire to have anything, and be anything that I was willing to work hard to achieve.
speaker: rubio

segment: But he taught me that in Spanish, because it was the language he was most comfortable in. And he became a conservative, even though he got his news in Spanish.
speaker: rubio

segment: And so, I do give interviews in Spanish, and here's why — because I believe that free enterprise and limited government is the best way to help people who are trying to achieve upward mobility.
speaker: rubio

segment: And if they get their news in Spanish, I want them to hear that directly from me. Not from a translator at Univision.
speaker: rubio

segment: Thank you, Senator Rubio.
speaker: tapper

segment: Senator Cruz — Senator Cruz, this week, we learned more about Dr. Carson's plan for the 11 million to 12 million undocumented immigrants in this country.
speaker: tapper

segment: Dr. Carson proposed giving these undocumented immigrants a six- month grace period to pay back taxes then to let them become guest workers and only to deport people who failed to do that.

segment: Not exactly what I said.

segment: Well, how would you say it, sir? I was just reading the Wall Street Journal quote, but please tell us.

segment: Well, what I said, after we seal the borders, after we turn off the spigot that dispenses all the goodies so we don't have people coming in here, including employment, that people who had a pristine record, we should consider allowing them to become guest workers, primarily in the agricultural sphere, because that's the place where Americans don't seem to want to work.
speaker: carson

segment: That's what I said. And they have a six-month period to do that. If they don't do it within that time period, then they become illegal, and as illegals, they will be treated as such.

segment: OK, from the horse's mouth, Senator Cruz, does that fit your definition of amnesty?

segment: Well, Jake, you know, I'm — I'm very glad that Donald Trump's being in this race has forced the mainstream media finally to talk about illegal immigration. I think that's very important.

segment: I like and respect Ben Carson. I'll let him talk about his own plans.

segment: But I will say this: The natural next question that primary voters are asking, after we focus on illegal immigration is, okay, what are the records of the various candidates? And this is an issue on which there are stark differences.

segment: A majority of the men and women on this stage have previously and publicly embraced amnesty. I am the only candidate on this stage who has never supported amnesty and, in fact, who helped lead the fight to stop a massive amnesty plan.

segment: In 2013, when Barack Obama and Harry Reid joined the Washington Republicans in a massive, I stood shoulder to shoulder with Jeff Sessions helping lead the fight.
speaker: cruz

segment: You know, folks here have talked about, how do you secure the borders? Well, I've been leading the fight in the Senate to triple the Border Patrol, to put in place fencings and walls, to put in place a strong biometric exit/entry system...

segment: Thank you, Senator.

segment: Senator Rubio...

segment: Can I — can I — can I just...

segment: ... I'm not sure...

segment: Can I correct...

segment: We'll come back to you — we'll come back to you in one second, sir.
speaker: tapper

segment: But Senator Rubio, I'm not sure exactly whose plan he's — he's saying is — constitutes amnesty, but I know he has said it about your plan in the past, so I want to give you a chance to respond, then, Dr. Carson, we'll come to you.
speaker: tapper

segment: OK.
speaker: carson

segment: Well, let me say that legal immigration is not an issue I read about in the newspaper. Immigration, illegal immigration, all the good aspects of immigration and all the negative ones as well, I live with. My family's immigrants. My neighbors are all immigrants. My in-laws are all immigrants.
speaker: rubio

segment: So I've seen every aspect of it, and I can tell you America doesn't have one immigration problem, it has three.
speaker: rubio

segment: First, despite the fact that we are the most generous country in the history of the world in allowing people to come here legally, we have people still coming illegally.
speaker: rubio

segment: Second, we have a legal immigration system that no longer works. It primary is built on the basis of whether you have a relative living here instead of merit.
speaker: rubio

segment: And third, we have 11 million or 12 million people, many of whom have been here for longer than a decade who are already here illegally.
speaker: rubio

segment: And we must deal with all three of these problems. We cannot deal with all three of these problems in one massive piece of legislation. I learned that. We tried it that way.
speaker: rubio

segment: Here's the way forward: First, we must — we must secure our border, the physical border, with — with a wall, absolutely. But we also need to have an entry/exit tracking system. 40 percent of the people who come here illegally come legally, and then they overstay the visa. We also need a mandatory e-verify system.
speaker: rubio

segment: After we've done that, step two would be to modernize our legal immigration system so you come to America on the basis of what you can contribute economically, not whether or not simply you have a relative living here.
speaker: rubio

segment: And after we've done those two things, I believe the American people...
speaker: rubio

segment: Thank you, Senator.
speaker: tapper

segment: ... will be very reasonable and responsible about what you do with someone who's been here and isn't a criminal. If you're a criminal, obviously, you will not be able to stay.
speaker: rubio

segment: Thank you, Senator.
speaker: tapper

segment: Senator — Dr. Carson...  ... I want to give you 30 seconds. I'd like you to answer the question.
speaker: tapper

segment: Senator Cruz describes plans such as yours as amnesty. Why is your plan not amnesty?
speaker: tapper

segment: My plan is not amnesty for a number of reasons.
speaker: carson

segment: Number one, you know, I've talked to farmers, and they said they cannot hire Americans to do the kind of job that I'm talking about.
speaker: carson

segment: And the second reason is because the individuals who register as guest workers, they don't get to vote, they are not American citizens, and they don't get the rights and privileges of American citizens. So that's key.
speaker: carson

segment: But the other thing that I want to bring up is, I mentioned something earlier. I think it was just sort of glossed over.
speaker: carson

segment: I talked about the success in Yuma County, I mean, incredible success, and the Department of Justice said, "No, we don't want to do that. That's too successful."
speaker: carson

segment: We don't have to keep reinventing the wheel. All we have to do is look at things that work. All we have to do is use a little common sense.
speaker: carson

segment: Thank you, Dr. Carson. I want to talk about the issue of birthright citizenship, which — which has emerged since the first debate as — as an a — a major issue in this campaign.
speaker: tapper

segment: Mr. Trump, you say that babies born in the United States to undocumented immigrants should not any longer get automatic American citizenship. Ms. Fiorina says that you are pandering on this issue and acting like the politicians that you rail against. What's your message to Ms. Fiorina on birthright citizenship?
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, first of all, the — the 14th Amendment says very, very clearly to a lot of great legal scholars — not television scholars, but legal scholars — that it is wrong. It can be corrected with an act of Congress, probably doesn't even need that.
speaker: trump

segment: A woman gets pregnant. She's nine months, she walks across the border, she has the baby in the United States, and we take care of the baby for 85 years. I don't think so.
speaker: trump

segment: And by the way, Mexico and almost every other country anywhere in the world doesn't have that. We're the only ones dumb enough, stupid enough to have it. And people — and by the way, this is not just with respect to Mexico. They are coming from Asia to have babies here, and all of a sudden, we have to take care of the babies for the life of the baby.
speaker: trump

segment: The 14th Amendment, it reads properly, you can go and — it's probably going to be have to be check — go through a process of court, probably ends up at the Supreme Court, but there are a lot of great legal scholars that say that is not correct.
speaker: trump

segment: And in my opinion, it makes absolutely no — we're the only — one of the only countries, we're going to take care of those babies for 70, 75, 80, 90 years? I don't think so.
speaker: trump

segment: Ms. Fiorina, the vast majority of countries do not have birthright citizenship...  ...Donald Trump is right about that. Why is it pandering when he's — he says this?
speaker: tapper

segment: First let me say, We have just spent a good bit of time discussing, as Republicans, how to solve this problem. I would ask your audience at home to ask a very basic question. Why have Democrats not solved this problem?
speaker: fiorina

segment: President Obama campaigned in 2007 and 2008 on solving the immigration problem. He entered Washington with majorities in the House and the Senate. He could have chosen to do anything to solve this pro — this problem. Instead, he chose to do nothing.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Why? because the Democrats don't want this issue solved.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Ms. Fiorina...
speaker: tapper

segment: They want it to be an issue that they can use. As to birthright citizenship...
speaker: fiorina

segment: Please.
speaker: tapper

segment: ...the truth is, you can't just wave your hands and say "the 14th Amendment is gonna go away." It will take an extremely arduous vote in Congress, followed by two-thirds of the states, and if that doesn't work to amend the Constitution, then it is a long, arduous process in court.
speaker: fiorina

segment: And meanwhile, what will continue to go on is what has gone on for 25 years. With all due respect, Mr. Trump, we've been talking about illegal immigration for 25 years. San Francisco has been a sanctuary city since 1989. There are 300 of them.
speaker: fiorina

segment: And meanwhile, what has happened? Nothing. The border remains insecure. The legal immigration system remains broken. Look, we know what it takes to secure a border. We've heard a lot of great ideas here. Money, manpower, technology...
speaker: fiorina

segment: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.
speaker: tapper

segment: ...mostly, apparently, leadership...
speaker: fiorina

segment: Thank you.
speaker: tapper

segment: ...the kind of leadership that understands how to get results.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina. Mr. Trump, I want to give you the chance to respond...
speaker: tapper

segment: I agree 100 percent, by the way, with Carly on the fact that the Democrats do not want to solve this problem, for the obvious reasons, but they do not.
speaker: trump

segment: But I believe that a reading of the 14th Amendment allows you to have an interpretation where this is not legal and where it can't be done. I've seen both sides, but some of the greatest scholars agree with me, without having to go through Congress.
speaker: trump

segment: If you do go through Congress, you can absolutely solve the problem.
speaker: trump

segment: Thank you, Mr. Trump. Senator Paul...
speaker: tapper

segment: But you — you would stipulate, Mr. Trump, but not everyone agrees with you.
speaker: fiorina

segment: That's true, sure.
speaker: trump

segment: OK.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Senator Paul, I want to bring you in. Where — where do you stand on the issue of birthright citizenship?
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, I hate to say it, but Donald Trump has a bit of a point here.
speaker: paul

segment: The case that was decided around 1900 was, people had a green card, were here legally, and they said that their children were citizens. There's never been a direct Supreme Court case on people who were here illegally, whether or not their kids are citizens.
speaker: paul

segment: So it hasn't really been completely adjudicated. The 14th Amendment says that "those who are here and under the jurisdiction." The original author of the — of the 14th Amendment said on the Senate floor that this was applying to slaves, and did not specifically apply to others.
speaker: paul

segment: All right. Senator Paul, thank you so much. Let's turn to a new topic. We've received a lot of questions on social media about the economy and about jobs. We have two CEOs on stage right now.
speaker: tapper

segment: Ms. Fiorina, you were CEO of Hewlett Packard. Donald Trump says you, quote, "ran HP into the ground," you laid off tens of thousands of people, you got viciously fired.
speaker: tapper

segment: For voters looking to somebody with private-sector experience to create American jobs, why should they pick you and not Donald Trump?
speaker: tapper

segment: I led Hewlett Packard through a very difficult time, the worst technology recession in 25 years. The NASDAQ stock index fell 80 percent. It took 15 years for the stock index to recover. We had very strong competitors who literally went out of business and lost all of their jobs in the process.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Despite those difficult times, we doubled the size of the company, we quadrupled its topline growth rate, we quadrupled its cash flow, we tripled its rate of innovation.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Yes, we had to make tough choices, and in doing so, we saved 80,000 jobs, went on to grow to 160,000 jobs. And now Hewlett Packard is almost 300,000 jobs. We went from lagging behind to leading in every product category and every market segment.
speaker: fiorina

segment: We must lead in this nation again, and some tough calls are going to be required. But as for the firing, I have been very honest about this from the day it happened. When you challenge the status quo, you make enemies. I made a few. Steve Jobs told me that when he called me the day I was fired to say, hey, been there, done that twice.
speaker: fiorina

segment: It's also true that the man that led my firing, Tom Perkins, just took —
speaker: fiorina

segment: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.
speaker: tapper

segment: — out a full-page ad in the New York Times to say he was wrong, I was right. I was a terrific CEO, the board was dysfunctional. And he thinks I will make a magnificent president of the United States.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.
speaker: tapper

segment: Well —
speaker: trump

segment: Mr. Trump — Mr. Trump, why would you be better at creating jobs than Carly Fiorina?
speaker: tapper

segment: — let me — well, let me just explain. The head of the Yale Business School, Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, wrote a paper recently, one of the worst tenures for a CEO that he has ever seen, ranked one of the top 20 in the history of business. The company is a disaster and continues to be a disaster. They still haven't recovered. In fact, today, on the front page of the Wall Street Journal, they fired another 25 or 30,000 people saying we still haven't recovered from the catastrophe.
speaker: trump

segment: When Carly says the revenues went up, that's because she bought Compaq, it was a terrible deal, and it really led to the destruction of the company.
speaker: trump

segment: Now one other company before that was Lucent. Carly was at Lucent before that. And Lucent turned out to be a catastrophe also. So I only say this. She can't run any of my companies. That I can tell you.
speaker: trump

segment: Ms. Fiorina, I want to give you a chance to respond.
speaker: tapper

segment: You know, Jeffrey Sonnenfeld is a well-known Clintonite and honestly had it out for me from the moment that I arrived at Hewlett Packard. But honestly, Mr. Trump, I find it quite rich that you would talk about this.
speaker: fiorina

segment: You know, there are a lot of us Americans who believe that we are going to have trouble someday paying back the interest on our debt because politicians have run up mountains of debt using other people's money. That is in fact precisely the way you ran your casinos. You ran up mountains of debt, as well as losses, using other people's money, and you were forced to file for bankruptcy not once —
speaker: fiorina

segment: I never filed for bankruptcy.
speaker: trump

segment: — not twice, four times, a record four times. Why should we trust you to manage the finances —
speaker: fiorina

segment: I'll tell you why; it's very simple.
speaker: trump

segment: — of this nation any differently than you managed the finances —
speaker: fiorina

segment: I'll tell you. I was running —
speaker: trump

segment: — of your casinos?
speaker: fiorina

segment: — Carly, Carly —
speaker: trump

segment: Mr. Trump.
speaker: tapper

segment: — I've made over $10 billion. I had a casino company — Caesars just filed for bankruptcy. Chris will tell you — it's not Chris' fault either — but almost everybody in Atlantic City is either in trouble or filed for — maybe I'll blame Chris.
speaker: trump

segment: Well —
speaker: fiorina

segment: But Atlantic City is a disaster —
speaker: trump

segment: Well, Mr. Trump —
speaker: fiorina

segment: Wait a minute, Carly. Wait. I let you speak. Atlantic City is a disaster, and I did great in Atlantic City. I knew when to get out. My timing was great. And I got a lot of credit for it.
speaker: trump

segment: Many of the great business people that you know — and Carl Icon (ph) is going to work with me on making great deals for this country. But whether it's Carl or so many others that we read about all the time —
speaker: trump

segment: Thank you, Mr. Trump.
speaker: tapper

segment: — they have used the laws of the land, which is the —
speaker: trump

segment: Governor Christie's name has been invoked. I'd like to give him a 30 second opportunity.
speaker: tapper

segment: Jake listen. While I'm as entertained as anyone by this personal back-and-forth about the history of Donald and Carly's career, for the 55-year-old construction worker out in that audience tonight who doesn't have a job, who can't fund his child's education, I've got to tell you the truth. They could care less about your careers, they care about theirs.
speaker: christie

segment: Let's start talking about that on this stage and stop playing — and stop playing the games. Stop playing —
speaker: christie

segment: There's a —
speaker: kasich

segment: John — I'm not done yet, John.
speaker: christie

segment: A track record of leadership is not a game. It is the issue in this election.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Stop — and stop playing — and Carly — Carly, listen. You can interrupt everybody else on this stage, you're not going to interrupt me, OK?
speaker: christie

segment: The fact is that we don't want to hear about your careers, back and forth and volleying back and forth about who did well and who did poorly. You're both successful people. Congratulations. You know who's not successful? The middle class in this country who's getting plowed over by Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton. Let's start talking about those issues tonight and stop this childish back-and-forth between the two of you.
speaker: christie

segment: Ms. Fiorina, I want to give you
speaker: tapper

segment: Jake —
speaker: kasich

segment: Governor Kasich, I'm coming to you next, but Ms. Fiorina's name was mentioned, and I have to give her the opportunity to respond if she wants it.
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, I thought we had been hearing quite a bit about Govenor Christie's record as governor, actually. I think track records are very important. I completely agree that what's at stake here is the future of this nation, and the future of every American.
speaker: fiorina

segment: But I do think that a track record of leadership is vital because in the end this election is about leadership. And let's talk about what leadership is. It's not about braggadocio, it is about challenging the status quo, solving problems, producing results.
speaker: fiorina

segment: And the highest calling of leadership is to unlock potential in others.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Thank you.
speaker: tapper

segment: Problems have festered in Washington for too long. And the potential of this nation is being crushed.
speaker: fiorina

segment: Thank you, Ms. Fiorina.
speaker: tapper

segment: Governor Kasich, I want to come — I'm coming to you. I'm coming to you. Let me ask the question. You can use the time however you want.
speaker: tapper

segment: OK, Jake.
speaker: kasich

segment: Donald Trump says that the hedge fund guys are getting away with murder by paying a lower tax rate. He wants to raise the taxes of hedge fund managers, as does Governor Bush. Do you agree?
speaker: tapper

segment: I don't at this point in terms of changing the incentives for investment and risk-taking.
speaker: kasich

segment: But let's just stop for a second. There's one person on this stage that does have a record. I'm the only person on the stage and one of the few people in this country that led the effort as the chief architect of the last time we balanced the federal budget.
speaker: kasich

segment: We also cut taxes. And when I left Washington in 2000, we had a $5 trillion surplus, and the economy was booming. I had spent 10 years of my life to get us to that point, went out in the private sector, was a great experience, and went into Ohio and took an $8 billion hole and turned it into a $2 billion surplus.
speaker: kasich

segment: We've had the largest amount of tax cuts of any sitting governor. We've grown well over 300,000 jobs. You see, I've done it in both places. I'm the only one here that has done it in both places.
speaker: kasich

segment: It took a lot to get us to a balanced budget. It was legitimate. It was real. And we negotiated it. A lot of what we're talking about here tonight as we take this position and that position, you know what? At the end of the day, America has got to work.
speaker: kasich

segment: We've got to figure out how we come together to deal with this — with our fiscal problems because when we deal with that, we create a stronger economy for everybody. People have a chance to rise.
speaker: kasich

segment: So, you know, when we think about how we make a choice, it's the person that lands that plane. It's not somebody that talks about it. It's about the person who has done it. And I've done it in...
speaker: kasich

segment: Thank you, Governor.
speaker: tapper

segment: ... both places. And I did it including people in the other party. And that's how we were successful.
speaker: kasich

segment: Thank you, Governor Kasich.
speaker: tapper

segment: And that's how I will be president, using that experience to drive this country forward. Thank you.
speaker: kasich

segment: Governor Huckabee, I want to bring you in on the question of hedge fund managers and taxing them. You have said that you are bothered by the fact that hedge fund managers pay such a low tax rate and make 2,500 times what people who work for them make.
speaker: tapper

segment: Do you agree with what Donald Trump and Governor Bush have proposed, raising their tax rates?
speaker: tapper

segment: I have a different idea. I think we ought to get rid of all the taxes on people who produce. Why should we penalize productivity? And it's why I'm an unabashed supporter of the "fair tax," which would be a tax on our consumption, rather than a tax on our productivity.
speaker: huckabee

segment: In other words, you're not going to tax anybody for what they earn, whether it's worker whose working by the hour or whether it's a hedge fund manager. If they can produce something and bring capital and labor to create jobs, we need some jobs. And I think the "fair tax" makes more sense.
speaker: huckabee

segment: Now, Jake, I've been listening to everybody on the stage and there is a lot of back and forth about I'm the only one who has done this, the only one who has done that, I've done great things.
speaker: huckabee

segment: We've all done great things or we wouldn't be on this stage. But it occurs to me as we're sitting here in the Reagan Library that most of us would like to pay tribute to a guy who, when he got elected, didn't get elected telling everybody how great he was.
speaker: huckabee

segment: He got elected telling everybody how great the American people were. And he empowered them to live their dreams, which is what I'd love to see us do by no longer penalizing the people who are out there working because they are taking a gut punch right now.
speaker: huckabee

segment: Thank you, Governor.
speaker: tapper

segment: Dr. Carson, you support scrapping the entire tax code and replacing it with a flat tax based on the principal on tithing from the Bible. If you make $10 billion, you pay $1 billion in taxes, if you make $10, you pay $1 in taxes.
speaker: tapper

segment: Donald Trump believes in progressive taxation. He says it's not right that rich people pay the same as the poor. Tell Donald Trump why his ideas on taxes are wrong.
speaker: tapper

segment: It's all about America. You know, the people who say the guy who paid a billion dollars because he had 10, he has still got $9 billion left, that's not fair, we need to take more of his money. That's called socialism. That doesn't work so well.
speaker: carson

segment: What made America into a great nation was the fact that we said, that guy just put in $1 billion, let's create an environment that's even more conducive to his success so that next year he can put in $2 billion.
speaker: carson

segment: And that's the kind of thing that helps us to grow. We can't grow by continuing to take a piece of pie, and dividing it, and redistributing it.
speaker: carson

segment: But, I'm also looking at what doctor — at what Governor Huckabee talked about...
speaker: carson

segment: ...You don't want me operating on you, I assure you. [laughter]
speaker: huckabee

segment: The Fair Tax. Looking at both of them, and evaluating them both, and I'm talking to the American people because one of the things we must recognize is that this country is of, for, and by the people. And, it's really time that the government get out of the way, and let the people be the ones who decide how they want to run their country.
speaker: carson

segment: Mr. Trump...
speaker: tapper

segment: ...Well, I'd like to respond, I'd like to respond...
speaker: trump

segment: ...What do you think of the flat tax? Do you think it's fair?
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, I think the thing about the flat tax, I know it very well. What I don't like is that if you make $200 million a year, you pay ten percent, you're paying very little relatively to somebody that's making $50,000 a year, and has to hire H&R Block to do the — because it's so complicated.
speaker: trump

segment: One thing I'll say to Ben is that we've had a graduated tax system for many years, so it's not a socialistic thing. What I'd like to do, and I'll be putting in the plan in about two weeks, and I think people are going to like it, it's a major reduction in taxes. It's a major reduction for the middle class. The hedge fund guys won't like me as much as they like me right now. I know them all, but they'll pay more.
speaker: trump

segment: I know people that are making a tremendous amount of money and paying virtually no tax, and I think it's unfair.
speaker: trump

segment: Thank you, Mr. Trump. Senator Paul?
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, I'm glad we're having a discussion about taxes because everybody laments that we lose jobs overseas, we have. Our companies, and our jobs are being chased overseas by a 70,000 page tax code, so, that's why I've chosen to get rid of the whole thing, and have one single rate, 14 and a-half percent for everybody, business, and for corporate income, and personal income. But, we also get rid of the payroll tax, so the working class would get a tax break as well.
speaker: paul

segment: So, I think a flat tax, eliminating the tax code, getting rid of all the loopholes, is the way to go, and it's the way we get America going again.
speaker: paul

segment: Governor Walker, I want to go to you. Dr. Carson wants to raise the Federal Minimum Wage, you have called it a lame idea. Why is raising the Federal Minimum Wage lame?
speaker: tapper

segment: So, the best way to help people see their wages go up is to get them the education, the skill they need, to take on careers that pay more than minimum wage. And, it's why we talk about it, it's all about jobs. You want to help actually get jobs, it's why on that last question we were trying to jump in on taxes. To me, it's not just about taxes, cutting taxes. I've done it as much as anyone has.
speaker: walker

segment: I've cut income taxes, I've cut property taxes. In fact, property taxes are lower today in my state than they were before we took office. The real issues about jobs.
speaker: walker

segment: Ronald Reagan, our plan is based on the Ronald Reagan tax cuts of 1986. That brought about one of the longest sustained periods of economic growth in American history. All the things we should be talking about tonight are about how do we create jobs, helping people get the skills and the education qualifications they need to succeed.
speaker: walker

segment: That's the way you help people create jobs. It's part of our large plan to reform the tax code, to cut taxes, to put in place an education system that gives people the skills and education that they need. To put in place all the above energy policy, but you start on day one with repealing Obamacare.
speaker: walker

segment: I'm the only one on this stage that's actually got a plan, introduced an actual plan to repeal Obamacare on day one. I'll send a bill up to Congress, and to make sure enact it...
speaker: walker

segment: ...Thank you, Governor...
speaker: tapper

segment: ...I'm going to sign an order that makes the Congress live by the same rules as everybody else.
speaker: walker

segment: ...Thank you, Governor...
speaker: tapper

segment: ...That will ensure they repeal Obamacare...
speaker: walker

segment: Dr. Carson, Governor Walker didn't really answer the question, but I'll let you respond. He called raising the Federal Minimum Wage lame, what do you think of that?
speaker: tapper

segment: Well, first of all, let me say what I actually said about raising the minimum wage. I was asked should it be raised, I said, probably, or possibly. But, what I added, which I think is the most important thing, so, I said we need to get both sides of this issue to sit down, and talk about it. Negotiate a reasonable minimum wage, and index that so that we never have to have this conversation again in the history of America.
speaker: carson

segment: I think we also have to have two minimum wages, a starter, and a sustaining because how are young people ever going to get a job if you have such a high minimum wage that it makes it impractical to hire them...
speaker: carson

segment: Thank you, Dr. Carson...
speaker: tapper

segment: ...Jake, Jake, Jake, I just want to address that issue because you said I didn't answer, and I did. I said, to me, I think the real focus shouldn't be — you know, Hillary Clinton talks about the minimum wage. That's her answer to grow the economy. The answer is to give people the skills and the education so they make far more than minimum wage.
speaker: walker

segment: I don't want to argue about how low things are going to be, I want to talk about how do we lift everyone up in America. That's what Reagan talked about. It wasn't how bad things were, it was how to make it better for everyone. That's what we've done in Wisconsin, that's exactly what we'd do as...
speaker: walker

segment: Let me bring in our partner from Salem Radio Network, Hugh Hewitt.
speaker: tapper

segment: I'd like to talk about winning because I think all of you are more qualified than former Secretary of State Clinton, and as were the people in the first debate, but there are different styles, and Carly Fiorina, Governor Kasich, you're conveniently located next to each other, and you have different styles.
speaker: hewitt

segment: Governor Kasich, you've been on my show a lot. You refused to attack Hillary Clinton, you just don't want to go there, you want to do the up with people. Go, Ohio, OK, and I like that.
speaker: hewitt

segment: Carly Fiorina, I don't have to bring up the Secretary of State — you bring her up, so [inaudible].
speaker: hewitt

segment: Which one of you is wrong? Governor Kasich?
speaker: hewitt

segment: Well, look, people still have to get to know me, so I want to spend my time talking about my experience reforming welfare, balancing budgets, cutting taxes, providing economic growth when I was in Washington, turning Ohio around. Eight billion in the hole, $2 billion surplus, up over 300,000 jobs, big tax cuts, strengthening our credit.
speaker: kasich

segment: All those things matter but, you know, as a young man in my first election in 1978, I defeated an incumbent Democrat. I defeated an incumbent Democrat in 1982; running on the Reagan program, I was the only Republican in America to defeat an incumbent Democrat that year.
speaker: kasich

segment: And then, when I won for election of governor, I was the first Republican to defeat an incumbent in 36 years, and the first person to have never run statewide out of politics for 10 years to beat an incumbent. That hadn't happened for 96 years.
speaker: kasich

segment: So, we'll get to the point where we'll talk about Hillary Clinton, or whoever the nominee is, record. But right now, I want to give people sense of hope, sense of purpose, a sense of unity, sense that we can do it. So...
speaker: kasich

segment: Governor.
speaker: hewitt

segment: You know, at the end of the day, I'm going to continue to talk about my record, because there is, did you ever notice when people run for office, they run for president, they make a lot of promises, they don't keep them.
speaker: kasich

segment: Thank you, Governor.

speaker: tapper

segment: Well, Jake, I was named U.S. attorney by President Bush on September 10th, 2001. And that next day my wife Mary Pat did what she did every day, she traveled through the World Trade Center and went to her office two blocks from the World Trade Center.
speaker: christie

segment: And after those planes hit, for five-and-a-half-hours after that, I couldn't reach her, didn't know whether she was dead or alive, and we had three children at the time, 8, 5 and 1.
speaker: christie

segment: And I had to confront what so many thousands of others in my region had to confront, the idea I might become a single parent, the idea that my life and my children's life might be changed forever.

segment: To be clear, what I said the other day was that we need to lift the political restrictions that are already in play. Barack Obama's administration has put political restrictions on the military personnel already in Iraq.
